PARA.TAB: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Margaret Reid) took the chair at 2.00 p.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Assistant Treasurer. Minister, can you confirm that foreign owners will be able to receive tax free capital gains of up to $5 million under the government's capital gains tax rollover for small business? If so, how is this in Australia's interests?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Short, Sen Jim

TALK.START.PARA: —The details in terms of the government's decision on capital gains tax rollover relief for small business were spelt out in detail in the budget.
—You should know it then.

—So should Senator Sherry because we had about two hours on the darned thing last night. All the details are contained in the budget. So far as the specifics of the question are concerned, provided that the small business owner or proprietor—whether an individual or proprietor—meets the tests laid down and set out carefully in the budget documentation, he or she will be eligible. What Senator Sherry's question is really all about is, `Why is the government prepared to go out of its way to do things to help the small business sector in Australia get back on its feet after 13 years of ravaging by an incompetent Labor government that paid no regard at all to the interests of small business?'

ANSWER.PARA: The decision in the budget in terms of capital gains tax rollover relief is part of a series of measures taken in the budget and before the budget to give relief and assistance to help small business to grow, to create jobs and to provide a higher income and higher living standards for all Australians. As we know on this side of the house, even if Labor has not yet realised it, the small business sector is the engine of growth in this country and we are totally committed to ensuring that it continues to grow and develop in the interests of all Australians.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I think we could take it as a yes to foreign owners being able to benefit from this measure. You didn't mention the words `foreign owners' once in your answer. Why should Australian PAYE taxpayers pay tax on all their income while foreign business people are able to avoid paying tax on capital gains income they earn from their Australian based companies?

—There are many companies in Australia that are foreign owned that are subject to Australia's taxation laws and subject to international agreements and the like, as my friend Senator Panizza said. Every taxation law in Australia relates to relevant people in Australia, be they foreign or Australian. The situation so far as this measure is concerned, being one of a multitude of measures that the government has taken in the budget to assist small business and lower and middle income Australians, is no different in that concept from any other part of the taxation law.

—My question is addressed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate and relates to the budget. Over the last few days housing affordability results and figures from the Federal Office of Small Business have shown how home buyers and small business are benefiting from lower interest rates. The government's budget aims to increase national savings and cut Labor's legacy of debt to take pressure off interest rates and to help all these groups and encourage growth. Despite this, Labor is proposing to sabotage the plans to reduce the debt it created—more than $7 billion. What will be the consequences if its proposals succeed?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome the question from the honourable senator because it's more good news for Australia, and a further demonstration of good government in effect. Yesterday, the Real Estate Institute of Australia released figures showing that Australians on average are now spending 28 per cent of their household income on home loan repayments compared with 30 per cent this time last year. Furthermore, last week's housing finance figures showed that the number of new loans approved in July leapt by 16 per cent. So housing affordability has improved and the home loan take‐up rate has increased. Australian home owners and would‐be home owners are benefiting under a lower interest rate policy. That is the first point.

ANSWER.PARA: The second point is that having reduced interest rates is good for small business and small business will also applaud the policies of this government. The Federal Office of Small Business reported on Friday that small businesses across the nation are expected to save around $110 million through cuts in variable interest rates alone. Madam President, you and all honourable senators would know that nothing is more important to small business than keeping interest rates low. It provides the capacity to grow, make profit and employ more Australians.

I remind honourable senators that the first official reduction in interest rates in three years came after this government got into office and the trends are therefore positive. The trends are positive because we are the first government that has been prepared to take hold of public expenditure, reduce it and take pressure off interest rates. Therefore, small business and home owners can be confident about the future. It is interesting to see that today's ABARE report picks up the same sentiment.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about low inflation?
—Listen to this, Senator Sherry. ABARE said:

ANSWER.PARA: The prospect of further reductions in Australian interest rates in the short term has improved given the outlook for continued low inflation and fiscal tightening announced in the 1996-97 budget.
In other words, giving the Australian government, the coalition government, full credit for the improvement that is occurring and further improvement that is likely.

It is important that these benefits are not put in jeopardy in this Senate by the opposition parties in this place voting down significant parts of the budget and therefore undoing the good work that is being done by this government. I simply draw the opposition's attention to the sentiments of people such as Ian Salmon of the Business Council of Australia who said, `You can be pretty sure that if the savings side of the budget does not get up, that's going to put pressure on interest rates.' In other words, if you vote down our budget, that puts pressure on interest rates to go up. The same sentiment was expressed by the National Farmers Federation; not surprisingly by the Real Estate Institute; and also the Chamber of Commerce and Industry.

So the trend is in the right direction. It is important that that trend continues. But it will only continue if the opposition parties in this place also recognise their responsibility and support the budget and the fiscal tightening that we have put in place.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Health and Family Services. Minister, I refer you to the recent decision by President Clinton to approve Food and Drug Administration laws, declaring that nicotine and tobacco is a drug subject to federal legislation. Why has the federal government not followed the US lead and lifted the schedule 7 exemption on nicotine and tobacco? Is it the case that the government has no intention of acting on this matter, as was claimed by a government source quoted in the Melbourne Age on 26 August this year?
—I will be very happy to get an answer from the minister responsible and get back to the senator.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Communications and the Arts. Does the minister believe that a partially privatised Telstra will be more efficient because it will be less subject to political interference? Is there any prospect of bipartisanship on this important issue?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard

TALK.START.PARA: —This is a very important question because Telstra is currently subject to the risk of political interference. If you look at the current provisions of the Telecommunications Act there is a power for ministerial direction and, of course, that can be used and abused in a variety of ways. There were two high watermarks of political interference. One was a few years ago when it was necessary for Telstra to have all its press releases approved by the office of the minister for communications. But even in more sinister fashion was the other occasion back before the May 1995 budget when you had Mr Keating essentially stockwhipping Mr Blount into handing over a special dividend of an extra $100 million a year for two years on top of their ordinary dividend, together with the early repayment.

ANSWER.PARA: So the risk of political interference is a very serious one. The proper approach to take is to ensure that you have transparent rules by which all carriers must play. I think that is a widely accepted rationale for privatisation but I did not realise quite how widely accepted it was until I read the transcript of the Townsville hearings of the Senate Telstra inquiry. Senators will remember there were only two witnesses interviewed there and that it cost about $25,000 to go there, which is about $3.34 per second.

The most interesting exchange on that day came from none other than Senator Kim Il‐Carr who made a very valid point—and I would be surprised if Senator Kernot would regard him as part of the Telstra privatisation cheer squad. It is quite clear from the evidence of that committee that Senator Carr has taken my advice and has made that to phone call to Fidel because what he said was this:

Would it not be the case in a privatised or partially privatised or more commercially focused operation that there would be less political interference and therefore would it not be the case that it would be a more efficient organisation?

I could not have said it better myself. Senator Carr is absolutely right. There is no doubt that his Damascus conversion is very welcome on this issue. He is quite right: in a partially privatised Telstra there will be less political interference; it will be a more efficient operation.

Just to make matters worse for him—if in fact he did not quite mean to put it in those terms—is the answer he got from Mike Reynolds. I know why you do not want to hear this one, Senator Carr, because Mike Reynolds was a former Labor mayor of Townsville. What did Mike Reynolds have to say? He said:
I have no doubt that with a privatised or partly privatised organisation we would have less political interference in that particular way . . .

There you have it. You have someone that I would be surprised would be accused of being ideological on this particular issue, who has finally seen the light. He is obviously sick and tired of the dirty deals that go on behind the back of the Sydney Town Hall. He does not like the arm twisting and the thuggery that goes on in the factional game.

Senator Carr has finally realised that you ought to allow businesses such as Telstra to operate commercially, not to have that political interference and to be as efficient as possible. He knows the benefits of efficiency, and I am delighted to welcome him aboard the cart. I think he deserves the commendation of the Senate for the approach that he has taken. I just hope that he will have more success in caucus, that he will be able to demonstrate the hypocrisy of the stance that his own party has taken and that he will take the opportunity to explain to Mr Beazley and Senator Schacht just precisely why this is the sensible approach to take. I very much welcome his conversion on a very important issue.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Does the minister believe that there is indication of further scope for bipartisan support for the important policy objective of the part privatisation of Telstra, given the compelling arguments in favour of privatisation made by the Leader of the Opposition in a speech to the National Press Club on 24 August 1994?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard

TALK.START.PARA: —This is when it really does start to hurt because we are talking about someone who ought to be in a position of responsibility. We know why Senator Carr is not on the front bench, but the reason that Mr Beazley is presumably there is so that he can demonstrate some leadership on the important issues facing this country. What did Mr Beazley say when he was actually a minister? He said:

ANSWER.PARA: The primary objective driving the privatisation program is to make Australia an efficient internationally competitive economy. . .

The focus of debate on efficiency measures such as privatisation and competition policy is often on job losses, but it is more important to realise that the efficiency gained from the pursuit of competition creates jobs.
He went on to say:
Privatisation fits in with the government's broader imperative to create jobs.

In other words, this is not an ideological argument; this ought to be an argument about how you can act in the best interests of consumers and Australian citizens. That is why it is desperately disappointing that someone like Mr Beazley should not now have the courage to express those same convictions in the way that he did only 12 months ago. (Time expired)

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Mackay, Sen Sue

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Social Security. Minister, do you recall saying on the 7.30 Report last Tuesday:

QUESTION.PARA: I have said it all along—and I continue to say it: we are about choice for families.

Do you recall, on the same program, Professor Peter MacDonald, of the Research School of Social Science at the ANU, saying that the budget `says to people—well, if you have children, then perhaps you shouldn't be working' and Professor Bettina Cass saying, `The bias against dual income families exists by making it more uncomfortable and difficult for parents to juggle work and family, and more costly for parents to juggle work and family'? Can you explain why there is such a stark difference between what you claim and what the experts say, namely, that the budget in fact reduces choice for women and families?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very interested that the senator has raised this question. She might be interested to know that the interview I gave for that 15 second grab was about 20 minutes in length, highlighting the difficulty that one has when trying to get a message across when a program perhaps has another line which they are wanting to run.

ANSWER.PARA: Unfortunately, I was very keen to get on the public record what choice for families really means from this government. It means the opportunity to choose whether one parent, not necessarily the mother, is at home when the children are very small, if the family chooses to do that. It means choice as to whether they provide child care themselves, whether they provide it through the informal sector, whether they provide it through family day care, whether they need out of school hours care or holiday care, or whether they choose to go down what has been the high cost option of the publicly funded community child‐care area. In all these areas, we are giving families choice.

I notice that the opposition is only prepared to have a slash and burn where there are people on higher incomes who are being affected by the government's actions. We have made it very clear that battlers are the ones who deserve the greatest attention, support and sympathy from the government. It is battling families that were our prime targets for assistance through our family tax initiatives, which were not just for families where a parent stayed at home, but also where there was any dependent child. So in a very real sense, we were looking after families.

We were looking after people with work and family responsibilities through the industrial relations reforms which will give greater opportunity for flexibility of hours, which will give greater opportunities for permanent part‐time work, which many of the unionists on the other side of the chamber would have spent some of their years making more difficult for women. Women trade unionists have told me over and over again of the lack of sympathy they have encountered in trying to make arrangements for more flexible working arrangements to deal with family responsibilities.

Through the retirement savings account, we have recognised that women will be in the work force as well as at home. What is not acknowledged by programs such as the one which the question was about is that women at different times of their lives have different needs. They may be young married women in relationships where there are two incomes; they may choose to stay at home for a little while when their children are babies and then they may be a one income family. They may go back into part‐time work and then they are a one and a half income family. Later on, when the children are older, they will very likely go back into the full‐time work force and be a two income family again.

That is up to the families to choose. It is not up to government to choose. We have been putting in place measures that make that real life cycle easier to manage. So we are not judgmental about whichever choice people make. We are trying to make it a fairer choice. Under the previous government we do not believe that the choice was as fair as it should have been.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. How do the government's initiatives on child care with regard to the budget actually enhance choice for women and families?

—The measures that we are putting in place for child care maintain the opportunities for child care across all the various forms of child care that I enumerated in my previous answer. We have also put in place substantial funding which will assist families with children with special needs. We are putting in place additional funding for families in rural and remote Australia. We are putting in place measures to help those high cost community child‐care centres re‐adjust their businesses so they are more efficient. We believe through all these measures families will find that they are benefiting. In addition, we are committed to 80,000 more child‐care places. What more can one ask of a family‐ friendly child‐care policy?

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Health and Family Services. The cuts in the budget for public hospital funding, some $312 million across all states, are apparently there because the states have been cost shifting. Could you please explain what has been happening with regard to cost shifting? What have the states been doing? Which states have been doing what? How are you going to spread those $312 million in cuts over four years across the states? Finally, given the enormous problems facing our public hospital system, is your government prepared to reconsider this move and, in particular, are you prepared to consider allocating the one per cent increase in the Medicare levy for high income earners directly into the public hospital system?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I am not certain that the brief which I have from the Minister for Health and Family Services addresses the specifics of the question. For the specifics that I do not address in the course of the brief, I will come back to the senator later.

ANSWER.PARA: The brief provided by the minister for health says that under current arrangements it is the state and territory governments which determine the total amount of funds available to the pubic hospital system, the budgets for individual hospitals and the arrangements—for example, casemix—under which they are paid, the number and the location of hospitals, and the range of services available at each hospital.

As you would realise, the Commonwealth makes a substantial contribution through hospital funding grants to the states and also contributes indirectly through financial assistance grants. Under the current funding arrangements, the total Commonwealth HFGs to the states rose from $3,080 million in 1988‐89 to $3,933 million in 1992‐93. That is an average increase of three per cent in real terms over that five‐year period.

The 1992 Medicare agreements resulted in an additional $2 billion from the Commonwealth for hospitals. The 1996‐97 budget estimate for Commonwealth payments to the states under the Medicare agreements is $4,796.5 million, an increase of $67.2 million, or 1.4 per cent on the 1995‐96 expenditure. That increase reflects underlying growth of 3.6 per cent for price or population indexation offset by cost shifting adjustment and other factors.

In the 1996‐97 budget context, the government tackled the longstanding problem of cost shifting by the states and territories to the Commonwealth. The $75 million cost shifting adjustment in 1996‐97 reflects the failure of states to comply with an agreement by health ministers back in June last year to desist from further cost shifting. Whilst grants have been reduced, expenditure by hospitals is also reduced as costs have been transferred to the Commonwealth medical benefits schedule.

In contrast with the trend in Commonwealth hospital funding, states funding to the public hospital system has not shown steady growth. An analysis of the data compiled by the Commonwealth Grants Commission shows that the states' contribution to hospital funding declined by about two per cent in real terms over the period 1989‐90 to 1994‐95, which are the most recent years for which data is available.

In 1996‐97, New South Wales will receive an estimated $1.535 billion in HFGs from the Commonwealth, which is an increase of $23.8 million on the 1995‐96 outcome and maintains funding in real terms. As I said to Senator Lees before, I will get further particulars relating directly to the details of her question.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, when you are seeking further details from the minister for health, could you please ask if he will again reconsider this move, considering the pressure that the public hospital system is under. Last June—you are quite right—all states agreed to stop cost shifting, but they are insisting that they have stopped cost shifting. So can you ask the minister what evidence he has of where the cost shifting is occurring, and who is doing what? My final question is: could you please again check whether he is prepared to look at allocating the increase in the Medicare levy directly into the state public hospital system?
—As I have already said, Madam President, I will follow up on the details.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Conroy, Sen Stephen

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Assistant Treasurer and Minister representing the Minister for Fi nance. I refer to the government's decision in the budget to save $1.9 billion by reducing assistance for research and development. Is the minister aware that a strong rebuke has been delivered to the government by a leading pharmaceutical company, CSL Ltd, the managing director of which has stated:

QUESTION.PARA: The great problem with our economy is we just don't have internationally competitive industries. And what do they do? They reduce the one thing that has substantially changed the culture of business in the last decade.

I ask the minister: what information does the government have on the impact of this budget measure on Australia's export capacity, and was this information available to the government at the time this budget decision was taken?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Short, Sen Jim

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Conroy for his question, the short answer to which is that the government remains totally committed to promoting Australian research and development. It has been in the vanguard throughout the years in doing that, and will continue to do so, and indeed—
—Rubbish! Absolute hypocrisy!
—By jove, I wouldn't talk too much, if I were you Senator Cook, about your role in research and development. We will come to that later if you would like to.
—Senator Short, address your remarks through the chair.

—In the budget, Madam President, we have announced a package that sees total Commonwealth government support for research and development in 1996‐97 exceeding $3½ billion to increase the effectiveness of the government's research and development contribution. It is focussing the assistance towards increased outlays on research and development and away from tax expenditures or tax concessions. That is a way which has been followed by many other countries in recent years, and I thought the opposition side of politics was similar.

ANSWER.PARA: The R&D tax concession is being retained but the government has decided to reduce the premium rate for deductions for R&D expenses to a maximum of 125 per cent. But that concession remains very highly concessional. It allows immediate deduction or rapid amortisation of expenditures which would otherwise be undeductible or amortised over a longer period. It remains generous compared with other countries.

As part of the government's package we have announced a new and additional support for R&D, establishing the START program, which is an anagram for strategic assistance for research and development. That START program provides a flexible package of assistance totalling $340 million over the next four years. It is being targeted to encourage large projects containing highly innovative, technically risky R&D that has strong support for commercialisation from the private sector. That START program will deliver more effective government assistance.

The government, I repeat, maintains massive support for R&D, largely through the universities. The election commitment to increase CSIRO's funding base by an additional $115 million over the next four years has been honoured. Funding for CSIRO alone is estimated to be $440 million in 1996‐97, rising to $509 million in 1999‐2000.

Madam President, the government's record is well and truly on the line on this issue. We are a great supporter of R&D. The package that we have produced in this budget will produce great benefits for the economy. That is on top of the economic policy measures that we have put in place to get interest rates down, to get business growing and to encourage further growth in the economy which will lead to further private sector as well as public sector research and development.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Does the minister stand by the government's claim that the impact of this budget measure will be spread equally across industries? What evidence can he point to indicating that this will be the case?

—I repeat that the package of R&D that we have presented in this budget is unequivocally very generous. It remains highly concessional in terms of taxation. It provides a major new program of grants to innovative and worthwhile programs under taken by the private sector. It will of course vary in its benefits from one industry to another and from one period to another. That has always been the nature of these things and always will be. So far as the overall impact on business, the private sector and the economy is concerned, it is unequivocally positive and is seen as such.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. The Prime Minister gave me a categorical commitment on 13 August in Sydney that he would meet the Dalai Lama were he in Australia at the same as the Dalai Lama. As the two men will both be in Australia, indeed in Sydney, next week, is the minister able to say that the Prime Minister will be meeting His Holiness the Dalai Lama and drop the pussy footing statements such as `is likely to' and `is considering doing so'? When the meeting takes place, will it be not just domestic take for political purposes but give as well? In particular, will the government be making it clear that it calls on China to release the world's youngest political prisoner, the six‐year‐old Panchen Lama? (Time expired)
—The Prime Minister is on record as saying that, subject to his commitments, he is likely to meet the Dalai Lama.
—He said he's considering it.

—He is out of the country at the moment, but he will be returning, and he has put his position on the record and that remains. I am pleased that Mr Downer was able to meet the Dalai Lama the other night in Sydney in a private capacity.
—As a religious leader?

—That is correct, Senator Schacht. The Dalai Lama is here as a highly respected religious leader of international renown. He is welcome in Australia. As I said, it was good that Mr Downer and his wife were able to meet him in a personal capacity in Sydney the other night. The Prime Minister's position is already on the record.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. What pressure from China or elsewhere has caused the Prime Minister to change his position from the one stated categorically to me that he will be meeting the Dalai Lama if the two are together in Australia—and they will be—to the position you now state that he is likely to be meeting the Dalai Lama? At that meeting, will the government make it clear that it opposes China's imprisonment of the world's youngest political and religious prisoner, the Panchen Lama, and make it clear it opposes the Saddam Hussein like repression by China of the Tibetan people?

—I find it somewhat strange that it is being suggested that protests on human rights issues in China should be delivered to the Dalai Lama. He is here in Australia as a respected religious leader and we welcome him to Australia. Mr Downer has met with him. Mr Howard has said on the record that, subject to his program, he is likely to meet with him also. Therefore, the answer that I gave a moment ago stands. I am a bit disappointment at the way the Labor Party has sought to politicise this visit, a la statements from Mr Brereton who said that Mr Howard should meet with the Dalai Lama and apologise, a la Mr Beazley's attempt to get into the act today and Senator Brown's attempt as well.
—Oh!
—Well you listen to what the Dalai Lama says is the purpose of his visit. He says the purpose of his visit is religion and education. You should listen to that.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Sport, Territories and Local Government. I refer the minister to the announcement in the budget that the federal government has reduced funding to the Australian Sports Commission by $4.7 million. Specifically, I refer to the comment by the minister, Warwick Smith, that he could not see the justification in the Commonwealth subsidising the administration of big league sports when justifying the withdrawal of $500,000 worth of subsidies to the AFL, the ARL and rugby union. Is the minister aware that the majority of these funds are used exclusively to fund the development of junior sport and other not-for‐profit sporting programs? How does the minister justify his cavalier attitude to the contribution of football to the Australian economy? Does he concede that this contribution is threatened if programs to encourage junior sport are stifled? Does the government believe that it has any financial role to play in this regard? (Time expired)

—As the honourable senator will be aware, there have been relatively modest cuts across the board, which have been necessary to address the very large deficit that we inherited from Labor. There has been no disproportionate cut in relation to sport. In fact, as you would know, Senator, and no doubt applaud, the Olympic program has been fully maintained. In what remains, the emphasis is on programs delivered to the young and delivered in the form of community sports. In many ways that is the distinction between the emphasis in our program and that program that was put down by the previous Labor government. We think that that is fair in all the circumstances and we are happy to stand by it.
—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Does the government believe that it has a genuine role in providing financial support in the promotion of junior sport?

—I just answered that our emphasis is towards junior and community sport, and that is the primary distinction between our program and Labor's program. It seems that Senator Lundy is actually applauding the bias that we have exercised in favour of junior and community sports.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs. It has been with growing concern and dismay that I have noticed insulting references in the higher education budget debate to these so‐called `rich and thick' buying places in universities. Could the minister lay to rest once and for all this offensive and irresponsible argument and outline the obvious benefits which the full fee‐paying places for Australian students will bring to the Australian university system?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Troeth for her question. Madam President, you may remember one occasion when I caused great mirth in this place. I did not understand a perfectly incomprehensible answer given by a then Labor minister and prefaced my supplementary with the introductory remarks, `I might be a bit thick—'. Since I am clearly not thin, that caused huge mirth, especially on what was then and still is the opposite side of the chamber to me.

ANSWER.PARA: In a colloquial sense, of course, and as part of the political to and fro, you might expect these sorts of jibes. Senator Robert Ray was good enough to tell me, I understand, across the chamber one day, I could be a sight screen for cricket or something. It was a bit of the pot calling the kettle black in that respect. But when you move into a serious debate about education policy, then the political jibes and the colloquial expressions go.

There is an attempt by some people to create the impression that full fee‐paying places is about reducing the number of Commonwealth‐funded places and, equally, to say that it is about reserving 25 per cent of those places for the so‐called rich. These assertions are completely false. A fee place at a university will be over and above, not instead of, Commonwealth‐funded places. Next year the government aims to provide 358,000 undergraduate places at Australian universities. We aim to have 6,000 more undergraduate places than the number of places provided this year. In 1998 we want the number of undergraduate places to rise to 364,000. So it is certainly our intention to not only maintain the number of undergraduate places but to increase it. There is no desire on this government's part to reduce the number of government‐funded undergraduate places—a point that was made in this place the other day.

But take a student who just misses out on his or her first preference, say, for dentistry and is instead offered a place in physiotherapy. What is so wrong about giving that person the option to pay for a place in dentistry if it means that a government‐funded place in physiotherapy is therefore opened up for a student to take a HECS‐funded place they otherwise would not have got? Is that person to be described as rich and thick?

Is Senator Harradine, who is not in this chamber and, according to his biography, does not have a degree but, clearly, with his salary would be described as rich compared to the rest of the community, to be described as rich and thick if, when he wishes to retire, he wants to buy a place? Is that a terminology that we will use for him? What about journalists like Alan Ramsay, Allan Reid or Niki Savva? Are these people, because they did not go to university and now could, to be described as rich and thick? This is a disgraceful piece of terminology for anyone who is genuinely interested in the education debate.

As Senator Carr and others who use this terminology would know, education is not meant to be just for the brightest citizens. In fact, a truly clever country would bring out the best in all its citizens, not just the brightest.Even the most discredited advocates of IQ testing would not use a term like `thick' to label somebody for their educational opportunities that they ought to have in front of them. Even the most discredited person would not do that any longer. Is this a term, Madam President, that we use to describe school children whose parents send them to a private school? (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I thank the minister for her answer and I ask: does the minister have further details of the way in which both students and universities will benefit from this scheme?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Troeth for that supplementary question because it leads me to draw attention to the fee‐paying MBA students. Are the fee‐paying MBA students, who are there because of policies introduced by Labor and putting money aside, to be described as rich and thick? —At the same time the government and the minister, to his great discredit, in a very cowardly way—and it happened again today—are attempting on some extraordinary basis to blame me for the decision to import the meat.

It is an amazing article. I hope Senator Boswell reads it. I hope the National Party senators in here read the article that was in the Australian yesterday. It is interesting reading indeed. QUESTION.SPEAKER: Ellison, Sen Chris

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

QUESTION.PARA: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs (Senator Herron), to a question without notice asked by Senator Bob Collins today, relating to funding for the Community Development Employment Projects program of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission.

I bring to the Senate's attention the fact that in the area of the community development employment program, the CDEP, this government will be spending $337 million more in our first four years than Labor did in its last four years. If Senator Bob Collins is trying to say that this government is attacking the employment and training opportunities of Aboriginal people, then he had better think again. He had better have a good look at the budget because, in relation to education and training accounts, we have around $344 which will be spent in 1996‐97, with a total of $1.3 billion over the next four years—a real increase of 12 per cent compared to the last four years.

There are four major programs which will be affected. The largest is Abstudy, essentially the equivalent of Austudy, which provides financial support to secondary and tertiary indigenous students—and that will allow $542 million over the next four years in the form of living allowances, assistance with fees and other educational expenses. There is the Aboriginal education strategic initiatives program, AESIP, which provides funding of $419 million over four years to educational institutions to improve opportunities and outcomes for indigenous students. This also includes additional funding of $143 million before the efficiency dividend over the four years from 1995‐96 provided in response to a 1994 review of the national Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander education policy, which found that indigenous people are the most educationally disadvantaged group in Australia. We have real programs with real increases in expenditure that deal with the training of Aboriginal people.

We have the Aboriginal direct assistance program, which provides educational support such as homework centres or tutorial assistance. For this program, $233 million will be provided over the next four years. ATSIC's major program is the community development employment project, with funding of $353 million in 1996‐97. There are currently 262 communities involved in such projects, with a total of approximately 28,000 participants. CDEP participant numbers have been quarantined in the budget, so no CDEP jobs are at risk and no current projects are in jeopardy as a result of budget decisions. Additionally, current and future allocations provide some capacity for natural growth of around 50 new participants per month.

If Senator Collins is trying to say that there has been a cut in funding, a cut in the government's assistance towards Aboriginal training and employment, then he is mistaken. And he is not only mistaken; he is misleading the Senate in saying so because those figures are from the budget announced in August this year. This government is totally committed to the training of young Aboriginal people; it is totally committed to providing maximum employment for Aboriginal people. In fact, our policy of reducing the budget deficit is in turn going to offer more job opportunities to Aboriginal people.

PARA.BREAK: With the native title committee I visited a training facility not far from the Marandoo mine site where Hammersley Iron was providing on the job training for Aboriginal people. That training program was indeed successful, and plant operators from the program were then eligible to go on and gain employment with annual earnings of somewhere between $35,000 and $50,000 a year. That was brought about by economic growth from the development of a new mine. That is what this government is going to do: it is going to create an economic climate where all Austral ians will benefit, where all Australians will have more employment opportunities. But in the meantime we have that increased expenditure. For Senator Collins to say that we are cutting back on that is just not right and he ought to have another look at those budget figures.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Schacht, Sen Chris

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

QUESTION.PARA: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for the Environment (Senator Hill), to a question without notice asked by Senator Brown today, relating to a meeting of the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) with the Dalai Lama.

Today and yesterday Senator Hill, representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Downer), made a very mealy‐mouthed effort to explain why the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) could not yet confirm that he will meet the Dalai Lama. I want to point out to the minister that in 1992 the then Prime Minister, Mr Keating, met the Dalai Lama on his last visit to Australia and did so without any of the prevarication that appears to have gone on on this occasion.

I cannot see why the same statement cannot be made now, to say that next week when the Prime Minister is back in the country he will certainly meet the Dalai Lama. I understand that when former Prime Minister Keating met the Dalai Lama it was as a religious leader and as a Nobel Peace Prize winner. I cannot see any reason why the Prime Minister or the foreign affairs minister or Senator Hill cannot give that reason right now without any embarrassment anywhere in the world, even to the Chinese government. The only embarrassment we are suffering now is within our own community. It is affecting our own record on human rights. I want to point out to the minister that over the last five or six years—

TALK.START.PARA: —You said he is a religious leader. There is a contradiction—

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Schacht, Sen Chris

TALK.START.PARA: —And a peace prize winner. Senator, I would point out to you that over the last few years there have been various reports tabled in the Senate, one of them by the Senate foreign affairs committee in 1996, which talk about the human rights problem in Tibet. The human rights report by the joint foreign affairs and defence committee in November 1994 also has comments about human rights abuses in Tibet. I want to draw attention to two reports which I am proud of and which I was involved in. One of them concerns the delegation I led to Tibet and China in 1991, which was an all‐party report. I want to quote paragraph 18, page 32, from that report of the delegation. It states:

ANSWER.PARA: The Delegation was struck by the overwhelming support it encountered for the Dalai Lama. This appeared to be pervasive in Lhasa and its environs, at least. Every temple boasted a host of photographs of the Dalai Lama (far exceeding those of the Panchen Lama); special quarters, impeccably maintained, were set aside for him in monasteries; at every turn, people of all ages, both ordained and laity, would request, almost beg for, photos of him. The public display of this support, and Chinese tolerance of that display, greatly surprised the Delegation.

Apparently, since then the government has cracked down on photographs of the Dalai Lama. I would also point out that in the first human rights report, tabled in this parliament in December 1992, the recommendation unanimously supported by that all‐party committee said:
This Committee believes that the Australian Government should continue to press for the Chinese Government:

. to respect the human rights of the Tibetan people, particularly those rights set out in the Universal Declaration of Human Rights which China has signed and the International Convention for the Elimination of Racial Discrimination and the International Convention against Torture and Other Cruel, Inhumane or Degrading Treatment or Punishment to which China is a party; and
. to enter into earnest negotiations, without preconditions, with the Dalai Lama and his representatives with a view to reducing the tension in Tibet.

TALK.START.PARA: —Was that unanimous?

—That was unanimous. All these reports are unanimous. I just want to conclude by saying that in all these reports evidence was given and included in this report on the abuse of human rights in Tibet. From the same report of the human rights subcommittee of December 1992 I want to quote paragraph 7.54 which says:

BREAK.PARA: AsiaWatch/TIN document lists, in the course of 75 pages, political prisoners, their cases and their status. The evidence is very specific. There are 360 cases identified by name, including 120 cases of those recently released. The `crimes' of the overwhelming majority are minor, peaceful acts of political protest. The sentences for this group are harsh, ranging from one year to life. Twenty‐eight percent were for terms of over five years. The information persuades this Committee of widespread injustice being perpetrated in Tibet by the Chinese authorities.

Those are the reports of the Australian parliament. It is about time that the government announced that next week when the Prime Minister returns from overseas he will meet the Dalai Lama, as Prime Minister Keating did in 1992. (Time expired)

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bourne, Sen Vicki

TALK.START.PARA: —I believe also that the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) should meet the Dalai Lama. I believe he will meet the Dalai Lama—I hope that is the case. Let me put to rest any fears he has of meeting the Dalai Lama by saying that I did meet the Dalai Lama this morning, along with all my colleagues in the party room. His message was one of peace and compassion—certainly no violence whatsoever.

ANSWER.PARA: The basic message that he wanted to give us was that he believes there need to be negotiations between the Chinese government and the Tibetan people—in particular, his own representatives—and that those are very important negotiations and negotiations he thinks can take place. He is not advocating at the moment self‐determination for Tibet; he is advocating a form of autonomy—suzerainty—for Tibet. That is something which many other governments are prepared to accept and advocate. I do not think a meeting with the Dalai Lama would be a problem to the current Prime Minister. I do accept and understand that we have got to the same level we got to the last time the Dalai Lama was here; and I hope we can do that again. (Time expired)
Question resolved in the affirmative.

PETITION.TITLE: Industrial Relations
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

We, the undersigned citizens, respectfully submit that any reform to Australia's system of industrial relations should recognise the special needs of employees to be protected from disadvantage, exploitation and discrimination in the workplace.

We, the petitioners, oppose the Coalition policies which represent a fundamentally anti‐worker regime and we call upon the Senate to provide an effective check and balance to the Coalition's legislative program by rejecting such a program and ensuring that:
(1) The existing powers of the Australian Industrial Relations Commission (AIRC) be maintained to provide for an effective independent umpire overseeing awards and workplace bargaining processes.

(2) The proposed system of Australian Workplace Agreements (AWAs) should be subject to the same system of approval required for the approval of certified agreements (through enterprise bargaining). Specifically, an AWA should not come into effect unless it is approved by the AIRC.

(3) The approval of agreements contained in the legislation should be subject to the same system of approval required for the approval of certified agreements (through enterprise bargaining). Specifically, an AWA should not come into effect unless it is approved by the AIRC.
(4) Paid rates awards be preserved and capable of adjustment, as is currently the case in the legislation.
(5) The AIRC's powers to arbitrate and make awards must be preserved in the existing form and not be restricted to a stripped back set of minimum or core conditions.
(6) The legislation should encourage the processes of collective bargaining and ensure that a certified agreement within its terms of operation cannot be over‐ridden by a subsequent AWA.
(7) The secondary boycott provisions should be preserved in their existing form.

(8) The powers and responsibilities of the AIRC to ensure the principle of equal pay for work of equal value should be preserved in its existing form. We oppose any attempt by the Coalition to restrict the AIRC from dealing with over‐award gender based pay equity issues.
(9) A `fair go all round' for unfair dismissal so that all workers currently able to access these remedies are able to do so in a fair manner, at no cost.
(10) Workers under State industrial regulations maintain their rights to access the federal awards system in its current form.
Your petitioners therefore urge the Senate to reject the above proposed reforms to the area of industrial relations.

PARA.TAB: that the overwhelming majority of Australians support uniform, national gun laws and the associated compensation measures as agreed between the Prime Minister, State Premiers and the Chief Ministers of the ACT and NT.

PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned strongly opposes the Government's proposed sale of one third of Telstra and urges the Government to meet its environment responsibilities from other revenue sources.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Broadcasting Corporation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

This petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the Senate your petitioners' appreciation of the vital role the ABC plays in the development of Australian culture and in the provision of quality news and information services, including in regional Australia.
Proposed alterations to the ABC charter and cuts to its funding and staff levels will have an extremely adverse effect on the ABC's performance of these roles.

Your petitioners express their grave concern that the Government proposes to break its unequivocal election promise to maintain current levels of ABC funding and proposes to redefine the ABC's role so that it has a narrower focus and is more politically acceptable to the Howard Government.

Your petitioners request that the Senate ensures the current ABC charter, funding and staffing levels are maintained so that the ABC retains its independence and viability as an effective national broadcaster.

PETITION.TITLE: Child Care
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned requests that in the interests of maintaining excellence and access to quality child care services for all Australian children and their families:
(1) The Parliament recognise the detrimental economic and social impact on families of all incomes from Budget cuts to Child Care services.
(2) The Parliament recognise the loss of public infrastructure if Community‐Based Child Care services are forced to close as a result of the abolition of operational subsidies.
(3) The Parliament recognise the value of the non‐profit child care sector in providing high quality, accountable and transparent services to the community.
Your Petitioners request the Senate vote against any legislation that implements 1996 Budget cuts to child care services and the removal of the operational subsidy.
